Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Training the Trainers in Pre-Research Coursework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supporting a workshop to nationally disseminate the educational materials and lessons learned during the PIs' earlier NSF-funded project, "EURO: Enhancing Undergraduate Research Opportunities" (award 1123068). In this earlier project, faculty from 3 large institutions collaborated in developing coursework to provide lower division undergraduate STEM students with research experiences that were less costly than traditional methods involving labs. EURO met the considerable challenge of increasing participation in early undergraduate research in an affordable way. This was done through the creation of courses and programs designed to teach general research skills, rather than only engaging students in specific disciplinary research activities. By focusing on "research-oriented" or "research skills" experiences, more students can engage research early in their undergraduate studies without major increased expense. The target audience for the current project is comprised of faculty and administrators interested in increasing the number of students involved in undergraduate research at their institution. The workshop organizers are drawn from the EURO team. All of them have taught these courses over the past four years. The workshop has a capacity for 27 participants who are expected to become trainers in this method. The organizers are committed to following up with the participants to support adaptation of this approach at the participants' home institutions.

The PI team is continuing to solicit and develop modules and information to share with practitioners of undergraduate research. Workshop participants will be expected to contribute to the research concept inventory problems previously developed, adding content from a broad range of institutions. By holding the workshop concurrently with the short course taught at the lead institution, the PI team is also planning to measure the effectiveness of this method of dissemination and determine if it is more effective than the conventional methods. If most of the participants follow through and set up their own regional training programs, using materials that the project team will make accessible, the train-the-trainers aspect of this project will have a substantial impact and also become self-sustaining.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop to provide skills to faculty, administrators, and staff to implement undergraduate research training skills programs was held concurrently with a student training program at the University of Central Florida (UCF) on June 13-17, 2017. Workshop participants observed a peer mentored short course (PMSC) in research training in action, and developed individualized plans to implement a student-centered training program at their home institution. Participants viewed co-locating the faculty and student workshops positively. Many participants viewed the breadth of the programming, which is applicable to all STEM fields, to be one of the strengths of the workshop. 

The workshop covered the content delivered in each training model.  Student activities during the PMSC were correlated with the faculty training so faculty participants could develop a vision of how this could be implemented at their institution. All workshop materials, including tools for assessing student learning achievements, are available at http://sburkett.people.ua.edu/workshop-materials.html

Twenty six participants from across the country attended the workshop.  About 50% have a centralized office of undergraduate research, about 50% have departmental or individual programming. About 50% of the participants were faculty members, and about 50% had a partial or full time appointment in an administrative role tied to undergraduate research. Figure 1 is a group picture of all participants and workshop leaders, June 13-17, 2017. Figure 2 illustrates the institutional type and geographic diversity of workshop participants.

Outcomes from the training workshop are summarized beneath each area (Intellectual merit or broader impacts):

Intellectual Merit: Educational materials developed while teaching courses in our Enhancing Undergraduate Research Opportunities (EURO) project illustrate how we view best practices for engaging undergraduates in a pre-research training experience. This workshop intends to share our experiences and materials with practitioners. We believe observing a short course in action is transformative in one?s understanding of how the process works; by holding the workshop concurrently with the PMSC at UCF, we will see if this method of dissemination is effective for engaging participants.

  • All but one of the workshop participants agreed that faculty training workshops run in conjunction with this relatively novel student training experience provided benefits for the faculty in developing their personalized implementation plan.
  • The workshop was useful for multiple groups (both experienced and relatively novice undergraduate research promotors). They appreciated help with ?bringing together things we already have on campus?.
  • Participants? developed their own personal goals from the workshop that were specific to their own institution.
  • Participant response to the workshop was generally positive.  Typical comments were:
    • "Some of the content for the SRA would have occurred to me, but other components would not have, and I now have a nice range of activities and assignments to consider."
    • "I appreciated being able to see firsthand how the peer mentor aspect is incorporated."

Broader Impact: The broader impact of this train-the-trainers workshop has the potential to impact a vast number of undergraduate students, many of them that could be at risk of leaving STEM degree programs. Moreover, if program attendees set up their own regional training programs, using materials that the project team will make accessible, our train-the-trainers program can be self-sustaining. Additional impacts of this workshop include the professional development of faculty and administrators that participate in the workshop. Trainers will come away with a better understanding of barriers that prohibit students from seeking undergraduate research opportunities and they will be more educated and able to institutionalize programs at their home institutions that can help students be more successful in the STEM disciplines.

  • A 6 to 11 month post workshop follow-up found the following. The participants plan to or have already tried the following models:  38% Peer mentored short course, 46% semester long seminar or some variation on a shorter time scale, 8% faculty led boot camp, and 23% are going to try some hybrid of the three that will work best at their institution. Some participants plan to or have tried two models, and therefore the participation sums to more than 100%.  
  • In the follow-up, participants identified the following barriers to implementing these training modules (1) Leadership at their institution is in transition, or other staffing changes, so plans put on hold; and (2) Lack of local faculty engaged in research. 92% of the participants plan to or have utilized materials that were provided at the workshop. This signifies the need for broad distribution of materials in reducing barriers to implementing training programs and there is no interest in reinventing the wheel.  
  • Several participants commented on the need and benefit for actively engaging at a national or regional level with other undergraduate research promoters.
